(English)
A spectacular book that lives up to its title and makes us thankful for the advances in medicine / biology in the last 150 years. The book tells the story of surgeon Joseph Lister, one of the pioneers of antiseptic surgery. Before that, any surgery was an open door to microbial infections and very bad outcomes were common in the (usually filthy) hospitals of the time. Like any disruptive discovery, Lister‚Äôs work was widely criticized and opposed by the medical establishment at the time. This is a point common to all science history books I read: how new ideas are fought and criticized. I always get the impression of how much delay in the scientific process was due to the resistance that may have managed to bend many people who did not have the energy to fight like Lister and others.
